I put it down to these factors/understandings/principles:
1. The Smaller drum had a much more intense heat inside of it as it was heated indoors at room temperature, creating a greater volumetric difference when cooled..
2. The Larger Drum did not have as strong a suction as it was heated outside and constantly had the outside temperature  combating the smaller heat source under the barrel.
3. The Smaller drum had no reinforcing ribs around the circumference of the drum so gave in much more easily, allowing a short spread of the structural failure.
4. The Large drum DID have structurally reinforcing ribs pressed into its construction, so the force required to make the drum implode was so much greater, when the structure did actually give in The load was spread in a form that had more stability. A Triangle is more stable than a hexagon.

I think I have an explanation for different imploded shape:
I believe it has something to with the Euler's Buckling Modes....
To simply it....the slenderness ration (given same material for both cyclinders) is different for both cylinders. As the larger 200L drum has large slenderness ratio (above a critical point lets say SLc....which is required for an equilateral implosion)...so it'll buckle in a simplest buckling mode i.e. an equilateral triangle, where as the smaller drum has a lower slenderness (lower than SLc) ratio leading it to implode is a more complex buckling mode.
This is a very quick explanation on Sat night....but I believe I have the right direction.
To understand how buckling comes into play draw a free body diagram of cylinder's cross-section (looking at it from top or bottom)...and you'll see that only the compressional forces in the sheetmetal are the real culprits.
Hope....I'm right

Your explanation of why a condenser is used in a steam turbine is incorrect. Where you are correct in saying that a larger change in temperatures creates more power output from the turbine, you are incorrect in saying that the condenser creates suction. The main reason for having a condenser is it takes much less power to pump a liquid than compress a gas back to the boiler after the turbine. That is why the steam is condensed out. It minimizes the pumping power required therefore creating a larger net power out from the system.

His explanation of what helps the steam turbine spin is not entirely accurate.  There needs to be a vacuum created to aid in the expulsion and condensing of the saturated steam - this is accomplished with an air ejector which uses part of the steam to create a venturi effect to draw a vacuum on the condenser.  This enables the rapid condensation of the high-energy steam to condensate liquid, which is then recycled back to the steam generators.  Just the condensing the exit steam is not enough.

The diameter/length ratio of the cylinder affects the type of mode of failure. 

A very small ratio (relatively skinny or long) cylinder would tend to fail by collapsing flat (2 sides) on itself at the middle of the cylinder then spread to either end where it's constrained  to stay a circle.

As the ratio increases (cylinder becomes relatively fatter or shorter) the number of sides created would increase from 2, to 3, and so on to infinity (cylinder becomes a disc).

Minimum volume is not an equilateral triangle, it would be something flatter. There are plenty of real world examples where vessels or large pipes collapsed under vacuum, and depending on the exact situation they tend to wind up flat, or flattish. When you design pressure vessels, you actually have to check if they will withstand full vacuum, and provide protection if it is needed.

Since the big barrel was relatively long enough, the atmosphere was able to equalize the pressure by doing as little boundary work as possible.  But since the diameter/height ratio was larger for the small barrel, the metal would need to be stretched in order to form an equilateral triangle (and obviously stretching metal requires a lot of work). Therefore, for the small barrel, the regular polygon with the least number of sides which would not require stretching the metal is a hexagon.
another option is that circles of different sizes can only achieve certain types of bends in the same way that you can only fit certain sizes of waves into a circle.

Perhaps the temperature inside larger drum cooled to a much lower temperature before imploding compared to the smaller drum. Thus the larger drum had to accommodate for a greater change in pressure than say the smaller drum...

The smaller drum is not only "smaller" (as in proportionally smaller), it is also a lot shorter in comparison to it's width and depth, or, since we are talking about a cylinder, it's radius.

Because of the properties of the metal, coupled with the smaller radius and shorter "body", there is a lot more resistance against the "walls"' movement toward the center,  and that resistance is what defines how many sides a (the resulting) polygonal cylinder will have in this case.

The first was to make the hexagon, but since it still had a vacuum in it, the bottom edge gave way as it has a crease similar to that of the 200 gallon drum. This allowed a portion of the drum to collapse again, but in a more confined section towards the bottom, which created more torque, along the now existent vertical edge, which caused the slight deflection of the top edge and plate you can see at 1:27.

They crumple in different patterns due to the difference in shape of the top edge of the drums. In the 20 gallon drum, the top edge is a concave "C" shape, which can resist higher forces of deflection. However, in the 200 gallon drum, the edge was a much simpler folded crease. This cannot resist such high deflection forces from the collapsing walls so the top plate can bend to accomodate the triangle. The top edge of the 20 gallon drum could resist it better, which is why it collapsed twice.

I have no proof of this, but here it goes: Imagine the vacuum inside like a bunch of wires attached to the walls, pulling towards the center. The vacuum is distributed over a large area, so each wire pulls with a low force. Now you start taking wires away, until the force is big enough to buckle the wall. If you imagine doing this to a tuna can with very rigid endcaps, I think you get at the reason for the different polygons. Thinking about the interior angles also helps make sense of it. A near perfect circle has the largest interior angles, approximately pi. A triangle has the smallest pi/3. The other polygons are in between. In order to get a small interior angle the material must give/bend more substantially. Makes sense that the more stable container would be unable to achieve the optimum.
